source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: The effects of controlling crystallographic texture, using a series of pseudoisothermal or falling temperature rolling schedules, on $3 1 5 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C$ tensile properties of annealed $6 . 3 \cdot \mathsf { m m }$ -thick Zircaloy-4 plate are discussed.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: annealed $6 . 3 \cdot \mathsf { m m }$ -thick Zircaloy-4 plate

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: The $\bar { 3 1 } 5 ^ { \circ } C$ elongation and reduction in area, in both directions, qualitatively follow the same type of second order relationship.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: The $\bar { 3 1 } 5 ^ { \circ } C$ elongation and reduction in area, in both directions, qualitatively follow the same type of second order relationship.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: At temperatures near, but above the $\alpha / \alpha + \beta$ transus, the basal poles are nearly coincident with the transverse direction

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: at temperatures between the recrystallization temperature and the $\alpha / \alpha + \beta$ transus temperature, the basal poles approach the plate-normal direction

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: at temperatures below the recrystallization temperature, the basal poles assume the usual cold-rolling orientation of 30 to 40 deg from the normal in the transverse plane

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk1

evidence_span: rolling in the temperature range 825 to $8 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ on the texture formed in zirconium sheet

evidence_span: rolling in the temperature range 825 to $8 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ on the texture formed in zirconium sheet

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: The goal of the present investigation was to evaluate several texture parameters as means for correlating $3 1 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ tensile properties of hot-rolled and annealed $6 . 3 \mathrm { - } \mathrm { { m m } }$ -thick Zircaloy-4 plate with the rolling schedules that formed the texture in the plate

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: hot-rolled and annealed $6 . 3 \mathrm { - } \mathrm { { m m } }$ -thick Zircaloy-4 plate

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: The early studies of texture in zirconium [1,2] reported only that the basal poles of the hexagonal lattice were aligned at about 40 deg to the normal to the plate in the plane defined by the normal and transverse directions

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: Cheadle [7], rolling $\mathbf { Z _ { \Gamma } } \mathbf { r } \mathbf { - } 2 . 5 \ \mathbf { N _ { b } }$ , were successful in developing a wider variety of textures

evidence_span: Rolling temperature is the most significant variable in establishing the texture of a Zircaloy-4 plate

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk6
evidence_span: If a plate is rolled above the $\alpha / \alpha + \beta$ transus, the basal poles are aligned in the transverse direction

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk6
evidence_span: If the temperature is below the $\alpha / \alpha + \beta$ transus but above the recrystallization temperature, the basal poles are aligned near, but not greater than 30 deg to the plate normal

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk6
evidence_span: Below the recrystallization temperature, the basal poles fall between 30 and 40 deg to the plate normal

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk6
evidence_span: Zircaloy tubes were cold worked 50 or 80 percent to a series of textures and annealed at 475 to $5 7 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk6
evidence_span: Tube specimens were creep tested under internal pressure at $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ with the transverse creep stress $1 5 2 \ \mathsf { M P a }$ for $2 4 0 \mathrm { h }$

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk6
evidence_span: Annealing at 510 to ${ 5 2 0 ^ { \circ } } \mathbf { C }$ in the temperature range of partial recrystallization gives maximum transverse creep strength

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk6
evidence_span: The creep strength maximum is higher the lower the degree of cold work

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk6
evidence_span: Complementary creep tests under tensile load showed that the creep strength is lower transversely than longitudinally

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_015_chunk6
evidence_span: The transverse creep strength dependence on texture variations indicates that more radial basal poles give lower creep strength than more tangential basal poles
